description: From Middle English falteren (“to stagger”), further origin unknown. Possibly from a North Germanic source such as Old Norse faltrask (“be encumbered”). May also be a frequentative of fold, although the change from d to t is unusual.

examples: Tom, who isn't paying much attention, is suddenly caught by the falter in his voice as he reads the two lines—

verbs.description: falter (third-person singular simple present falters, present participle faltering, simple past and past participle faltered)

entries.meaning: To waver or be unsteady; to weaken or trail off.
(transitive, intransitive) To stammer; to utter with hesitation, or in a weak and trembling manner.
examples: And here he faltered forth his last farewell.

entries.meaning: To fail in distinctness or regularity of exercise; said of the mind or of thought.
(figuratively) To lose faith or vigor; to doubt or abandon (a cause).
examples: And remember, comrades, your resolution must never falter.

entries.meaning: To hesitate in purpose or action.
To cleanse or sift, as barley.
